So after around 2 hours it starts fetching data with 

$select=aboutMe%2Cbirthday%2CbusinessPhones%2Ccity%2CcompanyName%2Ccountry%2CcreatedDateTime%2Cdepartment%2CdisplayName%2CfaxNumber%2CgivenName%2Cid%2CimAddresses%2CjobTitle%2Cmail%2CmailNickname%2CmobilePhone%2CmySite%2CofficeLocation%2CotherMails%2CpostalCode%2CproxyAddresses%2Cstate%2CstreetAddress%2Csurname

Nothing else is returned.

I can see in the log my change request contains:

```
> {"emailAddresses":[{"address":"test@example.com"}],"personalNotes":null,"displayName":"Example, Test"}
```

and the following response contains (shortened for brevity and privacy):

```
"emailAddresses":[{"name":"Example, Test","address":"test@example.com"}]
```

Maybe this could help?

target_title: Sending long e-mails fails

note.body:
Okay, then it's EWS. It's better then. I do not know why it should break this way, the less why the debug prints should workaround the problem, unless it's a timing issue and the prints slow down things it a way that prevents the problem. Hard to say.

Could you try to open the EWS Mail account properties and turn on "Always connect with HTTP/1" in the Receiving Options tab, please? I'm wondering whether it'll have any impact on this. If you do not see there the option then the libsoup3 version does not allow it for the lib users. Then:

```
   SOUP_FORCE_HTTP1=1 evolution
```

may work similarly, only for every libsoup3 connection.

By the way, do you connect to the outlook.office365.com or a company Exchange server? And if a company, do you know the version of it, please?

target_title: Sending long e-mails fails

note.body: Because I would rather not compile & install newer evolution, I am tempted to make a workaround by putting `EWS_DEBUG=2` into gnome launcher and redirecting log to `/dev/null`.

target_title: Sending long e-mails fails

note.body:
The account type says ews. I do not have flatpak evolution installed. As I wrote, I ran evolution from command line, too with command `evolution >& ews_no_debug.log` and it was identical as running with the launcher. Only if I set `EWS_DEBUG=2` then I can send long e-mail.

Desktop launcher has the following line for running evolution `Exec=evolution %U`.

target_title: Sending long e-mails fails

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. I suppose the account type, in the Receiving Email of the Mail account Properties, says "Microsoft 365" (m365), not "Exchange Web Services" (EWS), maybe?

You are at the right place, both are covered in the evolution-ews project, they only use a different protocol to talk to the Exchange servers.

Being it the m365, I'm sorry to say that, but the 3.52.3 is kinda bad in this respect. The current stable series, 3.54.2, contains a lot of fixes in the m365, including for the mail part and also for the message sending itself. You better update to the latest version, if you want to stay with the m365. Or use the older EWS protocol, if possible. I'm sorry. The m365 is very new, thus it had/has many bugs.

The "Broken pipe" error is odd. It seems like either reading from the file broke or the server disconnected unexpectedly. Why it behaves differently when running from a terminal and from the launcher is even more weird. Can it be you've installed also a Flatpak version of the Evolution, which the launcher runs? The Help->About may show that. Or `ps ax | grep evolution` can provide a hint what processes are running in one or the other case.

target_title: Sending long e-mails fails

note.body:
If I start evolution from the OS (Ubuntu) provided icon or with

`evolution >& ews_no_debug.log`

sending a long e-mail reports the following error in the GUI:

```
Error while Sending message

Error sending data: Broken pipe
```

If I start it with

`EWS_DEBUG=2 evolution >& ews.log`

sending long e-mails works.

When I start it without EWS_DEBUG=2 the log is empty. So I have nothing to send.

target_title: Calendar: Import of event with DURATION incorrect

push_data.commit_title: I#292 - Calendar: Import of event with DURATION incorrect

target_title: Calendar: Import of event with DURATION incorrect

note.body:
Okay, the problem was with the DURATION, not with the UTC time. The evolution-ews knew the start is in the UTC, but the end was not properly recognized and caused a mismatch. Then the evolution-ews asked for a time zone definition for the UTC and the user-configured time zone, to which the server returned only the definition of the user-configured time zone, which saved the event as with the user time zone, instead of the UTC and user time zone.

There was also a problem with the start/end timezone setting, which I fixed as well. Interestingly, with only the timezone fix the import fails with an error `EndDate is earlier than StartDate` returned by the server, because evolution-ews tried to save the StartDate the same as the EndDate, but the start in UTC and the end in the user time zone, which is UTC+1 for me at the moment. That's an expected error, from my point of view (it shows a problem in the evo-ews code, or in the component values).

target_title: Calendar: Import of event with DURATION incorrect

target_title: m365: Calendar: Incomplete importing and floating time zone issue

note.body: Thanks for a bug report. I see both of the events have floating times, not referencing any time zone (despite the .ics file contains a timezone definition). The floating time means "at this time, in whichever timezone the user looks on the event".

target_title: m365: Search Organization contacts by default

note.body:
I did not add the org contacts read blindly, it does read the org contacts here, even without the `OrgContact.Read.All` scope, it does reach the (top level) `/contacts` end point. Or maybe it's because I use an app ID created within the company, under the same tenant.

One problem, the `OrgContact.Read.All` requires admin consent. That means nobody will be able to use it unless an admin approves it. That's sort of blocker, especially for the personal accounts. And another problem, when I try to add the scope into the app I get an error: `Unable to save changes. One or more of the following permission(s) are currently not supported: OrgContact.Read.All. Please remove these permission(s) and retry your request.`

Could you try to change the app ID to the third from [the wiki page](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution/-/wikis/EWS-OAuth2#available-application-id), please? It's provided by Microsoft, maybe it'll work. It's tricky to convince Evolution to re-sign to the server with the changed application ID, the easiest is probably to change the app ID in the mail account Properties, then open Seahorse and locate `Microsoft365[you@company.com]` in the Passwords and delete it, then run `evolution --fore-shutdown` and then start the evolution. That will avoid any libsecret caches (if it has any such thing).

Hmm, evo-ews doesn't ask for any such, it currently uses:

```
#define MICROSOFT365_SCOPE	"Calendars.ReadWrite" \
				" Calendars.ReadWrite.Shared" \
				" Contacts.ReadWrite" \
				" Contacts.ReadWrite.Shared" \
				" Mail.ReadWrite" \
				" Mail.ReadWrite.Shared" \
				" Mail.Send" \
				" Mail.Send.Shared" \
				" MailboxSettings.Read" \
				/* " Notes.Create" */ \
				/* " Notes.ReadWrite.All" */ \
				" offline_access" \
				" People.Read" \
				" Tasks.ReadWrite" \
				" Tasks.ReadWrite.Shared" \
				" User.Read" \
				" User.ReadBasic.All" /* User.Read.All requires admin approval */
```

note.body:
The gnome-keyring-daemon should be auto-started on demand, through D-Bus (and in the code through libsecret; evolution doesn't talk directly to the gnome-keyring-daemon).

Maybe it failed to start or it stopped unexpectedly for some reason.

I'm closing this, but feel free to add comments, I'll answer what I'll know.

target_title: Office365-Requesting access token, please wait... forever...

Hmm... maybe it was just the keyring wasn't started.

I ran the keyring manually (gnome-keyring-daemon) and that did the trick. Since I'm not running Gnome, I assume that's a "bug" in evolution or Kubuntu that it isn't starting that daemon.  Is there a recommended way to start that in my profile or startup to make sure it isn't missing in the future?

Thanks for the steps to help diagnose!  It was amazingly helpful.

Kelly

target_title: Office365-Requesting access token, please wait... forever...

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. What is the evolution version, please? Do you have gnome-keyring-daemon running, please? I'd expect an error message in the logs, or in the terminal, if there's any problem talking to the gnome-keyring-daemon, but maybe there is nothing for it.

My first idea was that there's something wrong with the token refresh, but your log shows it succeeded, thus it has got (I guess) stuck on some follow up code.

Could you install debuginfo packages (I think they are called `-dbg` in your distro) for the libsoup3, glib2 and evolution-data-server packages and then, when it'll wait in this state, capture a backtrace of the `evolution` process, please? It'll show what it is doing, where one thread should contain `e_oauth2_service_receive_and_store_token_sync`. You can get the backtrace with a command like this:
```
   $ gdb --batch --ex "t a a bt" --pid=`pidof evolution` &>bt.txt
```
Please check the bt.txt for any private information, like passwords, email addresses, server addresses,... I usually search for "pass" at least (quotes for clarity only), before sharing it anywhere. Ideally delete anything encoded (not readable by the humans), just in case to not expose anything private.

By the way, to write the multiline code blocks, you can use three back-ticks or tildes before and after the code block, as shown [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/help/user/markdown#code-spans-and-blocks).

target_title: Office365-Requesting access token, please wait... forever...

target_title: Office365-Requesting access token, please wait... forever...

note.body:
Sorry, a few more pieces of additional information.

1. I'm on Kubuntu 24.10, so it's possible it's a Gnome missing some components issue (maybe)
2. I've tried both with/without custom tenant ID and app ID configuration.  The outcome appeared to be the same (i.e. it took me through login and the same thing happened)
3. I've also tried the "Fetch URL" thing for the setup screen and that also had the same outcome (hangs on the same spot as screenshot above).
4. As mentioned above, I have evolution installed over a year ago on Kubuntu on my laptop (same account and settings) and it works just fine (though I haven't tried to login to get a new token recently).  That Kubuntu was 20.04 or 22.04, I think, and has since been upgraded to 24.04 using the package manager upgrade process (not a reinstall).
5. The laptop (working) is running KDE plasma 5.27.11 with Qt 5.15.13 and kernel version 6.8.0-48-generic (64 bit)
6. The desktop (not working) is running KDE plasma 6.1.5 with Qt 6.6.2 and kernel version 6.11.0-9-generic (64 bit)

push_data.commit_title: eds-I#570 - Adapt to libical icalrecurrencetype changes

target_title: Be able to select a resource/shared mailbox from M365

note.body:
The Microsoft Exchange has multiple ways how to share data between the users. One is the impersonation, which you currently use and which requires special setting on the server. Another is per-folder sharing, where the owner gives permissions to certain users for various access types (read-only, read-write, ...).

The Exchange Web Services (EWS) protocol does not have a discovery of the "what the other users share with me", but it can add the folder with "File->Subscribe to folder of other EWS user" menu option, which the m365 lacks currently.

target_title: Be able to select a resource/shared mailbox from M365

note.body:
Adding a new account subscribing to another mailbox works. I did checked the Graph API and there is no way of discovering which mailboxes a user has access to, like calendars do.

Since the option is there and it works I'll close it.

target_title: Be able to select a resource/shared mailbox from M365
m365: Calendar color reset on calendar list refresh

note.body:
The above commits are for 3.55.1+ and 3.54.2+

Couple issues here:
* Microsoft provides the calendar colors as named constants, while the web UI can choose more colors; they map some of them under the same name, even they are different; luckily, they also provide a `hexColor`, which is more accurate, though only as a read-only property; better than nothing
* the mapping of the color name to an actual color was not correct in the evo-ews code, thus they looked differently in the evo and in the web UI, even they had been read (with a proper or a wrong color name)
* I made it similar to WebDAV sources, the display name and the color is synced from the server only if the user did not change it; once the user renames the calendar, or changes its color, in the evolution, the server-side changes are ignored.

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. The Microsoft 365 currently does not support subscribing to the shared mailboxes, like the Exchange Web Services accounts can do with File->"Subscribe to folder of other EWS user..." menu option. The closest is to create a new Microsoft 365 account and check "Open Mailbox of other user", but it's far from the simple subscription to a single mail folder.

The shared calendars are advertised by the server, if I recall correctly, because they are added in the Web interface. Does it work to add the shared mailbox in the web interface? To have the evolution's UI refreshed sooner, you can restart the application together with the background processes using `evolution --force-shutdown` or `flatpak kill org.gnome.Evolution`.

target_title: Be able to select a resource/shared mailbox from M365
Mail: Show last-found folders even when server is unreachable
Mail: Show last-found folders even when server is unreachable

note.body: I believe this is not evolution-ews specific, it'll be better to be dealt with in a common place, in the libcamel, maybe with a little help on the evolution side, thus I move this to the evolution-data-server project for now. It can be moved elsewhere if needed.

target_title: m365: Search Organization contacts by default

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. While EWS (and MAPI) has concepts like "Global Address List", the Microsoft Graph API doesn't have any such thing, the apps need to check the organization contacts on various places. The items in the Microsoft graph API cannot be fetched "all at once", it's done in batches, which are relatively small. If you've thousands of the contacts in the organization, then it'll take its time. The server back even "back you off", which makes it take even longer (the server can "decide" you do to many requests and it'll tell the client to wait for 30 seconds, multiple minutes, it depends). The initial fetch always takes time, depending on the content size.

The list of the books may show a spinner beside the organization contact book, indicating "it is doing something". When you hover a mouse cursor above it it'll show a tooltip with the information about what it is doing.

Did it finish the initial fetch meanwhile?

target_title: m365: Search Organization contacts by default

note.body: Note: The MS365 contact folder "Contacts" with my manually added contacts works fine.

target_title: m365: Search Organization contacts by default
m365: Sometimes accesses server without OAuth2 token
m365: Sometimes accesses server without OAuth2 token

note.body:
Okay, found it. A code comment led me to the https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libsoup/-/issues/196 , but it's not precisely it.

The `e_soup_session_maybe_prepare_bearer_auth()` triggered a race condition, where two threads prepared two bearer authentication objects, the later overwrote the previous one, but the libsoup still used that "older" (due to the libsoup's 196) and when the ESoupSession wanted to refresh the OAuth2 data, it used the newer one, instead of that in the libsoup internals.

The fix might be to avoid the race condition. As the code resides in the evolution-data-server, I move this there.

target_title: m365: Sometimes accesses server without OAuth2 token

note.body:
After some debugging today, the problem is after the call to `soup_auth_is_ready()`, which returns `FALSE` for the `ESoupAuthBearer` structure, which results into no authentication header being passed to the server. That can happen when the `e_soup_auth_bearer_is_authenticated` returns `FALSE`, which is when there's either no token set on it or when it's expired, but I checked the token is set and it is not expired.

Unfortunately, another libsoup thread crashed the evolution-calendar-factory process and I've been forced to restart it, which made it work properly again, thus I'm waiting until it'll reproduce, after which I can continue the debugging.

target_title: m365: Cannot delete instance of a recurring event

note.body:
The above commits are for 3.55.1+ and 3.54.1+

The code was all there, it was only triggered when the event had a detaches instance. It was supposed to be triggered when the event was recurring instead.

push_data.commit_title: I#284 - m365: Cannot delete instance of a recurring event

target_title: m365: Cannot delete instance of a recurring event

push_data.commit_title: I#284 - m365: Cannot delete instance of a recurring event

target_title: m365: Cannot delete instance of a recurring event

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. I can confirm it. My steps:
* create a new recurring event in a Microsoft 365 calendar, which recurs every day for 5 times
* right-click the third instance and choose "Delete this instance"
* the view flashes, the third instance is back

I see in the log the calendar backend sends a `PATCH` request with no changes `{}`, which is obviously wrong.

target_title: m365: Cannot delete instance of a recurring event
